review.title: Understanding opinions. A cognitive and formal account
review.abstract: The study of opinions, their formation and change, is one of the defining topics addressed by social psychology, but in recent years other disciplines, as computer science and complexity, have addressed this challenge. Despite the flourishing of different models and theories in both fields, several key questions still remain unanswered. The aim of this paper is to challenge the current theories on opinion by putting forward a cognitively grounded model where opinions are described as specific mental representations whose main properties are put forward. A comparison with reputation will be also presented.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text: In this preparatory work, we have tried to construct a cognitively based dynamic opinion model, in which we defined these mental representations as carachterized by the presence of three specific characteristics. In contrast to psychological theories of opinions, which usually provide rich definitions that are too complex to reduce to measurable variables, we have isolated three essential constitutive elements that characterize this type of mental representation. On the other hand, we have tried to overcome the reductionist approach of opinion-dynamic models, in which the wealth of human cognitive processes is replaced by easily calculable factors that are little related to actual human behaviors. For this reason, we have proposed to apply time-varying diagrams to develop a formal model that is capable of taking into account the way opinions are generated and changed depending on the presence and opinions of other actors in the network. We are fully aware of the complexity of this problem, and this work represents a preliminary attempt to combine cognitive opinions with a cognitive approach.
